data.title: Repeated prompts for GitHub credentials
data.body:
I have a private repo on GitHub that I've checked out using GitHub Desktop and then opened as a folder using Visual Studio Code.  I receive repeated prompts for my GitHub username and password.  If I cancel out of the dialog, it comes back about 5 seconds later.  If I enter my credentials, it goes away for a slightly longer period of time but still comes back.  It should be possible to make the dialog go away and stop bothering me.

I'm running Visual Studio Code 1.12.1 on Windows 10 Anniversary Update.

data.title: Fluent Design
data.body: I love VS Code. I love it so much that I have made like 12+ extensions for it and reported 20+ issues and gave talks about it. In Emacs vs Vim fights, I always talk about vscode and I find everything about it amazing and better than any other editor. It has exactly all that is needed and has removed exactly all that is junk. So it's awesome, but when it comes to design it's not the best UI on the planet and so many people just use Atom because it's cute: If you look at them they have round corners in the tabs, they have multi-layers of borders and shadows and sci-fi like coloring and huge paddings. This makes it very cute Ever since the first leak photos of Microsoft's new design language, I thought what if VS Code be redesigned in it and just as I heard that Microsoft finally announced it I felt like talking about it here. I know that UI is one of the biggest parts of VS Code. Just recently #3112: "Support to theme the entire workbench" issue was closed that was one of the biggest features and I get it that it's really a huge task but I feel like a pretty and cute editor can be the final act. Issues like #12377 show that this is not only my request. I know how the tiniest of details can sometimes be hard to implement (#26113) and I know how much of a big request this is. However, I think is so much worth it if a cuter prettier VSCode is out there. For example. Look at the auto-complete in Atom vs VS Code: Atom actually has very bad icons and VS Code has some of the best, cutest best-colored icons that could be in the application. However, just because of better shadows, round corners and no border design in the Atom, it looks better there. If only some basic design concepts are changed within VS Code and if it is implemented in the way of Fluent Design Language it could be much better than any other editor/IDE.

data.title: Please add an interface around `git add -p`, `git reset -p`, and `git commit -p`
data.body: These operations are enormously helpful when crafting a clean repository. The command line dialog for these sub-commands can be a bit arcane. A nice GUI would improve the the workflow tremendously.

```xml
    </filter>

</phpunit>

```

data.title: [1.12.1] editor.acceptSuggestionOnCommitCharacter not being respected
data.body:
I'm working in C#. I like suggestions, but I never want Code to accept them without my explicit say so, such as the tab key.  So I turned off `acceptSuggestionOnCommitCharacter` in my settings.json file:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3144427/26013076/cdc6a77a-3724-11e7-9131-ab0cea33a3f2.png)

But it still accepts the suggestion when I press `.` or `)`.

![vscode-issue](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3144427/26013407/388c2f84-3726-11e7-92cf-b463a92de406.gif)

Am I misusing this setting?

data.title: Git Checkout: Add save and recall editor files on branch change
data.body:
When moving between branches the working git file space obviously changes to the requested branch .

The open editors remain the same, yet typically one would be working with a different set of files
for the different branch.

Proposal:
git workspace command/option git.saveEditorFileSetOnCheckOut 
(or something of the sort)
probably give the user option to recall or not on branch change.

I would sign up to work up on this if deemed useful.

data.title: (Feature request) Allow toggling of intellisense by keyboard shortcut.
data.body: It seems Visual Studio already has this feature, but it would be convenient to be able to toggle off intellisense when writing docstrings, for instance.

data.title: Ability to have custom output panels
data.body:
For our project we are creating a language extension for our DSL which basically returns tables. We would like to be able to evaluate our dsl and have a nice HTML table output integrated in the IDE. 

The output channels aren't suitable as they don't take HTML.  Outputting tabulated text is t really an option. We may want to offer sort. 

Currently we used a HTML preview virtual tab to display those tables,but it's not very useable as they dock horizontal. The real estate at the bottom pane would be much more usable. 


Can we expose an contribution point to have custom panels next to the Terminal and Output tabs? Or allow docking of the HTML preview tab in there?

data.title: Scrolling search results with a large file is VERY slow
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.13.0-insider (f6ab171ab619a988b84fd1b91bb76e65847115a2, 2017-05-12T06:11:44.129Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.16193
---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open the `out` folder of a vscode build (`C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft VS Code Insiders\resources\app\out`)
2. Open the search widget and search for `codelens`
3. Expand the `workbench.main.js` node and make sure the window is small enough to need to scroll the results
4. :bug: Scrolling is extremely slow (and my CPU fan turns on)

Also note with that large file node (`workbench.main.js`) collapsed there is no lag when scrolling -- so it like vscode is trying to read from that file or something while scrolling.

data.title: Test: debug step improvements
data.body:
Refs: #25605

- [x] any os @egamma 
- [x] any os @roblourens  

complexity: 3

Make sure to test both the `legacy` and the `inspector` adapter. In order to test the `legacy` adapter make sure you have the `"protocol": "legacy"` in your `launch.json`, for `inspector` adapter have `"protocol": "inspector"`.
Take a javascript / typescript repository (example: [smoke test repo](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-smoketest-express)) and debug it. Verify:
* The callstack view is nicely showing the call stack as in previous vscode versions
* For long callStacks there is a "Load more stack frames" button which does what is expected
* You can step very quickly through the code and the variables and the callStack view will be fully updated only once you are no longer fastly stepping
* Debug the [typescript repository](https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript) and verify stepping performance is much improved. [Here are steps](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/5645#issue-150305742) on how to configure debugging in that repo.

data.title: Bug to select second of two themes with the identical names
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu 14.04

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install 3rd-party "Monokai Theme" (0.0.2 currently) from extensions manager.
2. Now there are 2 "Monokai" entries in **File->Preferences->Color Theme**:
  2.1. First one is **built-in** "Monokai".
  2.2. Second one is **3rd-party** "Monokai".
3. Select second "Monokai" (see 2.2). I want to use this one, because it doesn't change workbench colors. See https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/25986 for a reference.
4. **F1-> Reload Window**.
5. VS Code chooses the **first** "Monokai" theme (see 2.1.) **always**.

![two_monokai](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5967447/25999292/38fce20e-372d-11e7-95ee-2ba24a00d7a3.png)

I think VS Code selects Theme by name, not by identifier, and it always selects the first one.

3. In other ts files, I use let strTemp = localize('devicestate.connected.text', 'Connected');
4. The strTemp always 'Connected'. In fact, I want it's ''.

data.title: Gulp Compile-Build Error For Missing darwin/Credits.rtf When Building on Linux
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04 Docker Container

## Issue

Building vscode on a Linux machine should not require an OSX resource to be present

## Steps to Reproduce

1. Start with the source code for version 1.12.1 (using the commit hash from product.json)
2. Install npm modules
3. Run `gulp compile-build` in the main directory
4. The following error appears:

~~~
fs.js:584
  return binding.open(pathModule._makeLong(path), stringToFlags(flags), mode);
                 ^

Error: ENOENT: no such file or directory, open '/home/vscode/resources/darwin/Credits.rtf'
    at Object.fs.openSync (fs.js:584:18)
    at Object.fs.readFileSync (fs.js:491:33)
    at Object.<anonymous> (/home/vscode/build/gulpfile.vscode.js:109:70)
    at Module._compile (module.js:571:32)
    at Object.Module._extensions..js (module.js:580:10)
    at Module.load (module.js:488:32)
    at tryModuleLoad (module.js:447:12)
    at Function.Module._load (module.js:439:3)
    at Module.require (module.js:498:17)
    at require (internal/module.js:20:19)
    at require.sync.forEach.f (/home/vscode/gulpfile.js:76:17)
    at Array.forEach (native)
    at Object.<anonymous> (/home/vscode/gulpfile.js:76:4)
    at Module._compile (module.js:571:32)
    at Object.Module._extensions..js (module.js:580:10)
    at Module.load (module.js:488:32)
~~~

5. If an empty Credits.rtf file is created at the location mentioned in the error message the `gulp compile-build` command proceeds successfully

data.title: User Snippets add extra unneeded characters
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12+
- OS Version: MacOS

Steps to Reproduce:

1. add this javascript snippet in user snippet (there are tab in it) : 
```
	"function () =>": {
		"prefix": "function () =>",
		"body": [
			"($1) $2=> {",
			"	$3",
			"}"
		],
		"description": "Crer une function flche"
	},
```
2. invoke it

You will get something like that, with an extra comma :
![snippet](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5599375/25997462/63e91c50-371c-11e7-8d21-1e6f62592c3c.gif)

data.title: TypeScript type definitions not working with JavaScript in TypeScript projects
data.body:
I'm working on a project with mixed TypeScript and JavaScript. We use ThreeJS, and we use type definitions for it. The project itself is a TypeScript project.

-----
- VSCode Version: 1.12.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a tsconfig.json, add three.d.ts, and add a JS-file
2. Try typing something like `var world = THREE.Vector3`;

Excepted: VSCode doesn't complain about THREE.Vector3, and uses type definitions to provide IntelliSense.

Actual result:
VSCode complains "Cannot find name 'THREE'.", and doesn't provide IntelliSense.

-----

If I set allowJs to true in tsconfig.json, type definitions are used, but usually in exchange, I lose JavaScript type inference, and I don't want to compile my JavaScript code.

I also tried adding jsconfig.json, but it doesn't help as long as tsconfig.json is present.

I made a project that demonstrates the problem:
https://drive.google.com/open?id=0B4T6ZT_UgfRjcG5jM3QyblZPZHM

Thank you for making VSCode!

data.title: Hide unusable SCM controls when SCM not active

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
There are commit message input field and changes counter displayed at Source Control tab even SCM is not active/available.
- User can enter any text as commit message but Ctrl+Enter do nothing.
- Changes count is always 0 even if files are modified and saved.

Both commit message input field and changes counter should be hidden when SCM is not active in current vscode session.

1. Single file opened in editor, no workspace dir opened - no SCM available to user
![code - no git file](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3155552/25994425/16753250-370e-11e7-8a19-7bbff6f40def.png)
There can be tip "Open project folder [Ctrl+K Ctrl+O] to manage source code versions" displayed in place of commit message input field.
Or the git icon from left side toolbar can be hidden if SCM panel is empty and no operation is available at this place.

2. Folder opened but SCM not initialized - only change SCM provider or repo init are available to user
![code - no git dir](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3155552/25994248/79f28964-370d-11e7-84b4-c55d4d9246ed.png)
There can be tip "Initialize repository in this folder to start manage source code versions" displayed in place of commit message input field and changes counter.
